Iâ€™ve been following your channel for years, and itâ€™s been amazing to watch you grow and to do the things that you make happy. Iâ€™ve been so inspired by you over the years that I didnâ€™t even realize the impact youâ€™ve had on my life until recently. Iâ€™ve always loved your simple approach to food and physical and mental health. To the outsider, yeah, your life looks so put together, but I know that itâ€™s taken a long time for you to reach this point. Youâ€™ve always been open with your struggles about your anxiety and your approaches to how you handle your mental health. And I really appreciate that you talk about mental health in general. Thereâ€™s always been this stigma surrounding mental health and I just really think itâ€™s so important that we as a society peel back this ideology that mental health is a taboo topic. As a nursing student, Iâ€™ve learned how important it is to be in touch with your mental health. How you feel mentally affects how you feel physically. Whether people want to admit that or not is not something I can force. Although, if you really think about it, it does makes sense. And this whole deal with the pandemic had really the highlighted the pit falls in the mental health field and we, the healthcare professionals, have a long way to go to make it better for the patients.

So, Nicole, I think itâ€™s really great that youâ€™re talking about how youâ€™re feeling as a mom. Having a baby is a big change in your life and I wish that you could see other moms because having a sense of community is so, so important no matter where you are in life. Human connection and social interaction are essential. Youâ€™re feelings are your own and nobody has the right to tell you otherwise. And youâ€™re not being ungrateful. Youâ€™re a being a human being who has emotions and experiences and expectations. And itâ€™s completely normal to want those things no matter what anyone else has to say. Youâ€™re a mother and thatâ€™s absolutely something to be proud of.

As a mom, the fact that you are producing any content let-alone the quality content you have been creating, is INCREDIBLE. Thank you for sharing your journey.

@Kyouryoku Senshi Hi. I write too (as a hobby but I have been properly published so I get it). I'd refer you to dozens of baby vloggers on YT who, frankly, dig a lot deeper into issues of post-partum, isolation, breastfeeding issues, spousal disconnection post-baby, etc. Nikole is doing her own story - fine - it's just not "on brand" or why I'm here (healthy eating). I've had 3 babies whom I breastfed for 12+ mo/ea. It's not anything I need to see again. (As to why I know baby vloggers, I follow a lot of home cooks who have babies but don't make them the center of their vids. The YT algorithm often refers me to the baby content so I'll sometimes cruise through them.)

I've enjoyed the baby content. As someone who doesn't have/want kids it's made me a better writer as I do write a lot of family/baby stories. That said, I do miss seeing more of the cooking/nutrition content (I started watching shortly before her pregnancy) and Nikole did say in December that her intent for the channel isn't for it to become a mom blog and that she plans to do more recipes, so lets be patient.
